Marg Bhavnagar Gujarat 364002 India Graphical abstract An effective and recyclable heterogeneous catalyst (Ru-HT) for CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid avoiding a base, remarkably afforded TON of 11389 in 24 h at 60 °C and 60 bar pressure in the mixed solvent of MeOH and H2O. The reaction containing CO2 and H2 has been investigated for the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid using ruthenium hydrotalcite (Ru-HT) catalyst. Ruthenium salt was introduced to the synthesis of hydrotalcite as an active metal center to develop ruthenium based heterogeneous catalyst. Hydrotalcite not only acted as a support for the active metal but also acted as a soft solid base avoiding the use of the liquid base, which is normally required under homogeneous conditions for the formation of formic acid from the hydrogenation of CO2. Reaction temperatures were in the range of 40–100 °C, total pressure 10–100 bar with an ideal 1:1 ratio of pCO2:pH2. The maximum Turnover Number (TON) of 11389 was obtained for the formic acid formation under the optimized conditions at 60 °C temperature and 60 bar total pressure, using a mixture of methanol:water as a solvent (5:1, v/v). Ru-HT catalyst was synthesised and thorougly characterized by FT-IR, PXRD, SEM-EDX and surface area analysis. The catalyst was effectively recycled up to 7 times without any loss in catalytic activity. Keywords Ruthenium Ruthenium hydrotalcite (Ru-HT) Heterogeneous catalyst CO2 hydrogenation Formic acid 1 Introduction The increased emission of carbon dioxide (CO2) because of combustion of carbon-rich fossil fuels (i.e. natural gas, oil, and coal) has made a detrimental effect on the environment. Continues escalation of CO2 concentration in the atmosphere has reached bizarre levels, which bring apprehension about climate change and rising sea levels [1–5]. Because of the primary position of CO2 as a greenhouse gas and the consequence of its emissions on the tribulations of environment revolution, CO2 has become the subject of great environmental concern. Consequently, the transformation of thermodynamically stable CO2 into the useful fuels and chemicals has attracted much interest towards CO2 utilization. Hence, the reduction of CO2 to an energy storage medium is a conceivable and an encouraging solution to the outstretched atmospheric CO2 level by impersonating the carbon cycle in the environment. In this concern, the use of abundant CO2 as C1-building block in the presence of a catalyst is a striking approach for the synthesis of useful chemicals and fuels for the development of a sustainable economy [6,7]. Utilization of CO2 is the great replacement of toxic chemicals (i.e. phosgene and carbon monoxide) used for the production of value-added compounds [8–10]. The processes based on the CO2 recycling are attracting the major scientific and technological interest among the feasible approaches to reduce CO2 emissions [11–15]. The hydrogenation of profuse, nontoxic, renewable and economical viable CO2 deserves attention for the synthesis of value-added products viz., formic acid/formates, cyclic carbonate, methanol, dimethyl carbonate, etc. [16]. Catalytic transformation of CO2 to formic acid and its derivatives via the hydrogenation process is one of the best atom inexpensive approaches for the utilization of the abundant C1 feedstock [17]. Formic acid is an important chemical amongst the other chemical products procured by CO2 utilization. It is used as a vital intermediate in many industries viz., dyeing, leather, food, agrochemical, to promote the fermentation of acetic acid, as coagulants in the rubber synthesis, an antibacterial agent in livestock feed and as a de-icing agent in many manufacturing industries [18,19]. Formic acid has a comparatively small H2 content in its chemical structure (4.4 wt%), though it is gaining considerable interest as a hydrogen storage material in the energy industries because it is easily transportable and storable [20]. The existing commercial process for the production of formic acid involved the use of methanol and toxic carbon monoxide in the presence of a strong base like sodium methoxide, which currently produced 800000 tons of formic acid per year [21,22]. According to a review published in 2014, the production of 1 ton of formic acid via this process release 3076 kg of CO2, the same amount of formic acid could be produced by the CO2 hydrogenation which could release only 100 kg of CO2 [23]. Therefore, in comparison with the conventional CO-based process, CO2 utilized production has the vast perspective to reduce the environmental impact. The synthesis of formic acid via the hydrogenation of CO2 is thermodynamically disfavored, as it comprises the reaction between the gaseous substances to produce a liquid product. Consequently, the reaction is endergonic having ΔG°298 = 32.9 kJmol−1 value in the gas phase as well as exergonic having ΔG°298=−9.5 kJ mol−1 value in the aqueous phase. Since Raney-nickel was first used as a catalyst, formic acid has been extensively studied and synthesised in the presence of sundry homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts which includes transition metals in their structures such as Ti, Fe, Ni, Ru, Rh, Ir, Pd, Mo and Au [24,25]. Transition metal catalyzed hydrogenation of CO2 is a dynamic area of investigation, as it provides a favorable methodology for the synthesis of formic acid by utilizing CO2 as a cheap and profuse material for industrial scale chemical synthesis [26]. All these reported methods require the presence of a base or an additive like ammonia, trimethylamine, PPh3, NaHCO3, etc., because the catalytic activity is considerably reliant on the basic pH of the reaction mixture as it can shift the equilibrium towards the formed product (Eq. (1) and (2)) [27,28]. S. K. Kabra et al. have reported polyurea encapsulated ruthenium catalyst, which has given the highest TON of 47600 using an ionic liquid as an additive and scCO2 as a solvent in only 4 h [29]. The [IrCp*(NN)X]Y complex on HBF had given a TON of 6400 when Et3N was used as a base/additive and H2O as a solvent at 80 bar pressure (1:1, pH2/pCO2) in 10 h at 120 °C [30]. Palladium on activated carbon was reported by J. Su et al. using NH4HCO3 as a carbon source instead of CO2 gas giving a TON of 1769 with 27.5 bar hydrogen pressure [31]. A TON of 2254 was reported by Liu and co-workers using Ru-complex supported on TB-MOP and Et3N as solvent together with PPh3 as an additive [32]. A TON of 7088 was achieved using KHCO3 and H2 (40 bar) in the presence of Pd/r-GO (1 wt%) catalyst [33]. [Ru(NHC4H9)(PPh3)xCly] have shown a TON of 1384 with 5 times more concentration of CO2 than H2 using PPh3/Et3N as additive/base [34]. A proficient hydrogen production can be achieved by the decomposition of formic acid, as it is an energy or hydrogen storage compound. At present, the extensively used procedures for the hydrogen production is occurring at the high temperatures (>150° or >200 °C), which are the reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS) and the steam reforming of methane gas [35]. High temperature (>150 °C) is useful for catalytic RWGS reaction which is 2.5 times more than the temperature employed in the present work thereby affording to avoid the formation of any side-products (CO formation or methane synthesis) by the RWGS reaction in the gas phase under the employed reaction conditions in the present investigation [36]. According to the past available reports, there are scarcer results of a heterogeneous catalytic system for the hydrogenation of CO2 with no additional base or promoter to produce formic acid. The direct and selective synthesis of formic acid via CO2 hydrogenation over a heterogeneous catalyst without accumulating any base or additive is favorable and needs to be investigated. Therefore, it is worthwhile to use the ruthenium hydrotalcite as a catalyst that combines the active metal site from ruthenium metal and a basic property from hydrotalcite required for the production of formic acid by CO2 hydrogenation. It is one of the best auspicious approaches for utilizing CO2 at moderate temperature. Development of ruthenium-grafted hydrotalcite as a heterogeneous catalyst is desirable because direct ruthenium grafted hydrotalcite by using RuCl3·xH2O is economically viable, instead of heterogenizing the homogeneous ruthenium complexes. Hydrotalcite is a soft base and this base like property in its structure makes it an important and proficient solid support required during the CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid. Thus, Ru-HT is reported here considering its advantages as solid, reusable and efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the direct CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid with a very good TON (11389) at moderate reaction conditions (60 °C and 60 bar (1:1, pCO2/pH2)) using methanol: H2O (5:1, v/v) as a solvent in 24 h without using base. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Hydrogen gas UHP/Zero grade (99.9%) and carbon dioxide UHP/zero-grade gas cylinders were purchased from Hydro Gas India Pvt. Ruthenium trichloride [RuCl3·xH2O] was acquired from Sigma–Aldrich, USA. Magnesium chloride [MgCl2·6H2O; 98%], aluminum chloride [AlCl3·9H2O; 98%], sodium nitrate [NaNO3; 99.9%] and sodium hydroxide [NaOH; 99.9%] were purchased from S.D. Fine Chemicals Ltd., Mumbai, India and used as received. A.R. grade methanol was purchased from Loba Chemie and was used without further purifications. The double distilled milli-Q deionized water was used for the synthesis of catalysts. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin–Elmer Spectrum GX FT-IR system using KBr pellets in the mid-IR region. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were made by Rigaku MINIFLEX-II (FD 41521) Powder X-ray Diffractometer. The samples were scanned in the 2θ range of 10–80° using CuKα (λ = 1.54178 Å) radiation and a Ni filter. The textural analysis of the samples was carried out by nitrogen adsorption at 77.4 K using a Sorptometer (ASAP-2010, Micromeritics). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed using Omicron Nanotechnology system with monochromatic AlKα through 1486.7 eV photon energy. FE-SEM (Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope) and EDX analysis were done on JEOL JSM 7100F instrument at room temperature. Inductive coupled plasma (ICP) optical emission spectroscopy (ICPS-2000) was performed on PerkinElmer, Optima 2000 for the determination of the concentration of Ru element. The formic acid product was analyzed on a UV–vis spectrophotometer-P80+ spectrophotometer in the wavelength range 190–800 nm. These measurements were performed in 1-cm quartz cells by taking methanol as a standard. The UHPLC analysis was done using a Nexera UHPLC instrument system SHIMADZU instrument. Preceding to HPLC analysis, all samples and standards were filtered using Axiva SFNY25XB Nylon HPLC Syringe Filter (25 mm filter diameter/0.45 μm pore size) and left undiluted. Formic acid was separated on a HiQSilC18HS HPLC Column (4.6 mm × 250 mm) operated at ambient temperature with an overall flow rate of 0.5 mL per min of a 0.1% phosphoric acid mobile phase and detected using an SPD-M20A, Prominence, Diode Array UV detector set to 190 nm wavelength. The sample injection volume was 20 μL. Analysis was completed within 30 min, and data were recorded using Lab solution Chromatography software. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Ruthenium grafted hydrotalcite was prepared by coprecipitation method at a constant pH adopting the previous research method [37]. Two separate solutions were prepared in 50 mL double distilled deionized water each, solution (A) having NaNO3 (0.079 mol) and solution (B) having RuCl3·xH2O (0.5 mmol), Mg(NO3)2·6H2O(0.0522 mol) and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (0.0144 mol). To the solution (A), solution (B) was added dropwise in the duration of around 45 min with continuous stirring at room temperature maintaining the constant 10 pH of the mixture with the help of 1 M NaOH solution. Final mass was then transferred into the Teflon coated stainless steel autoclave to age it at 80 °C for 16 h under autogenous water vapor pressure. The formed precipitate was filtered and washed carefully with hot distilled water to remove the unreacted ions present in the precipitate. The acquired filter cake was dried at 80 °C and the solid material was ground and stored under vacuum coded as Ru–HT in which the molar ratio of Mg/Al in the hydrotalcite (HT) was 3.5/1. Ru–HT was activated at 450 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace. As catalyst was recycled up to 7 reaction cycles, the recycled catalyst was named as RRu-HT. 2.3 CO2 hydrogenation The hydrogenation of CO2 was done in the specially made high-pressure laboratory having safety precautions for using hydrogen and conducting reactions at high pressure and temperature. All operations involving charging of gases were carried out in a well-ventilated fume hood. The reactor was charged with a known quantity of catalyst and a mixture of methanol and double distilled deionized water. Autoclave and vessel were then sealed and flushed with CO2 three times to remove air and was pressurized up to a final total desired pressure with CO2/H2 (1:1, p/p) at room temperature. The reactor was set to heat by a controlled temperature equipment at 60 °C. The stirring start to begin at 800 rpm as the inside temperature of the reactor reached 60 °C, which was considered as the starting of the reaction. After the desired time of the reaction, stirring and the heating was stopped and the reactor was allowed to cool to room temperature. The reactor was depressurized at room temperature and the vessel was opened and the reaction solution was collected by simple filtration to separate the catalyst. 2.4 Product analysis The hydrogenation product was analyzed by HPLC and the concentration of the formed product was confirmed by the standard calibration curve plotted using area vs. formic acid concentration at 190 nm wavelength. Formic acid peak was observed at 19 min retention time, which was completely detected as the same that of the standard formic acid peak (Fig. S1). The product was also analyzed spectrophotometrically by the chromotropic acid test and volumetrically by acid-base titration. A UV–vis, P80+ spectrophotometer in the wavelength range 190–800 nm was used for the analysis of the product formic acid. These measurements were performed in 1-cm quartz cells by taking methanol as a standard. Several repeated experiments were done to check the reproducibility of the reaction under identical reaction conditions and the obtained results were found in the range of 3% variation. 3 Results and discussion The Ru-HT catalyst was found efficient to catalyze the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid. Hydrotalcite belongs to the class of brucite-like layered double inorganic base of general formula Mg1−x Al x (CO3 2−) x/n (OH2) x + ·m(H2O) and the ruthenium was grafted with the hydrotalcite during the co-precipitation method for the synthesis of ruthenium hydrotalcite (Ru-HT). The Ru-HT was prepared by using Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and Ru(III)Cl3·xH2O with NaNO3 in 1:5:5 × 10−3 mol ratio respectively maintaining constant 10 pH using 1 M NaOH solution. 3.1 Characterization of catalyst The FT-IR spectra of fresh and reused Ru–HT (RRu–HT) are given in Fig. 1 . Both are showing the all characteristic bands of hydrotalcite [38]. The band showed at about 541 cm−1 is corresponding to the translation modes of hydroxyl groups, influenced by Al3+ cations. The presence of a band at 418 cm−1 is attributed to the Mg-OH vibrational mode. The bands in the low-frequency region (below 1000 cm−1) are related to Mg-OH, Al-OH and Ru-OH vibrational modes in brucite-type layers. The peak at the 664 cm−1 (ν 4) is assigned to the in-plane carbonate bending [39]. The bands at 950 cm−1 for the deformation of Al-OH and at 780 cm−1 for Al-OH translation were also observed. The asymmetric stretching vibration (ν 3) of carbonates appeared at 1350–1380 cm−1 and could be assigned to chelating or bridging bidentate carbonates (interlayer carbonates). There are many reports on carbonate ion used as a carbon source for the formic acid production [40]. Consequently, because of the participation of interlayered carbonate anions present in the hydrotalcite structure, there may be the devastation of free carbonate anions during the formation of formic acid. These confounded carbonates probably show the broadness in the peak at 1647–1350 cm−1 in the RRu-HT catalyst (Fig. 1) [41]. Further, the metal hydroxide vibrational modes in brucite-type layers of Ru-OH, Al-OH, Mg-OH may be converted into their respective metal oxide vibrational modes at 400–1020 cm−1 attributed to RuO2, Al2O3 and MgO. The appearance of the shoulders at 1435 and 1647 cm−1 are characteristic bands of H2O and CO3 2−, confirmed the formation of Mg-Al hydrotalcite. The shoulder present at 3000 cm−1is attributed to the hydrogen bonding between water molecules and the interlayer CO3 2− anions. The absorption band at 3500–3600 cm−1, in both (Ru-HT and HT) is considered to the H-bonding stretching vibrations of the OH group present in the brucite-like layer (Fig. S2). The PXRD patterns of the fresh catalyst and the reused catalyst is given in Fig. 2 , which shows the reflections at respective 2θ angles of typical characteristics of hydrotalcite [39]. The sharp, intense and symmetric peaks at lower diffraction angles (2θ = 10–25) and broad asymmetric reflections at higher diffraction angles (2θ = 30–50) corresponds to the Ru-HT and HT, which shows a good dispersion of aluminum and ruthenium in the brucite layers [39]. The sharp peaks were observed at 2θ = 8.5 and 20 in the PXRD graph of the (Ru-HT) catalyst, which was present in the PXRD graphs of only (HT) too. The (Ru-HT) catalyst PXRD patterns show that the characteristic original planes of the (HT) are retained after grafting of ruthenium ion in the brucite-like layer. The intensity of the (003) and (006) planes of the (Ru-HT) catalyst, which is directly related to the crystallinity of (HT), which were observed to decrease in comparison of primeval HT after the ruthenium metal grafted in it. However, lack of broadening of the 00 L plane peak of (Ru-HT) compared to PXRD patterns of the only (HT) sample, showed the absence of intercalation of ruthenium ion into the (HT) interlayer space (Fig. S3). The presence of CO3 2− anions in the interlayer space of HT (3.5) and Ru–Mg–Al (Ru-HT) catalyst was confirmed by the characteristic basal spacing of (003) plane; d003 = 7.65 Å. Any additional peaks corresponding to other crystalline phases were not observed in the PXRD pattern of Ru–Mg–Al. The decrease in the crystallinity on grafting the ruthenium cations in hydrotalcite structure (Ru–Mg–Al) could be ascribed to the increase in the number of cations of higher ionic radii in brucite layers. The increase in the value of α was also observed for Ru-Mg-Al sample (3.069 Å) as compared to primeval HT (3.064 Å) due to larger ionic radii of ruthenium (0.805 Å) as compared to aluminum (0.53 Å). The decrease in the value of unit cell parameter c was observed for Ru–Mg-Al sample (23.38 Å) as compared to the value for HT (3.5) (23.41 Å). These results in a decrease in charge density on layers due to weaker interaction (or decrease in Coulomb attractive force) between the negatively charged interlayer anions and positively charged brucite-like layers [38,42]. The new extra peaks were observed in the PXRD of the recycled catalyst (RRu-HT) at 2θ = 30–35, 42 and 53 that could be consigned to the RuO2 phase generated during the catalytic activity corresponds to tetragonal rutile origination of ruthenium ion [43]. Not all these peaks were observed in the fresh one may be because of ruthenium ion is bonded with the hydroxyl groups (Ru-OH) present in the hydrotalcite before the formation of RuO2 species took place during reaction [43]. Moreover, there is an availability of carbonate anions in the hydrotalcite layer, which may be taking part into the formation of formic acid during the CO2 hydrogenation leads to the generation of new peaks in the PXRD pattern in the RRu-HT showing the desolation of interlayered carbonate anions from the HT structure [41,43]. The pore size, pore volume and the surface area of Ru-HT catalyst shows diminished values for the hydrotalcite-HT. The pore size for HT is 26.18 nm and pore volume is 0.72 m3g−1, while the pore size and pore volume of the Ru-HT are reduced to 17.4 nm and 0.33 m3g−1 respectively. The surface area of HT and Ru-HT is 101 m2g−1 and 76.2531 m2g−1 respectively. This diminution in the texture of Ru-HT is in the line of the superiority of the coverage of the pores and the external surface of HT by the involvement of Ru. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis has been done to know the oxidation state of ruthenium adopted for Ru-HT catalyst. Two binding energies are there in the Ru3d region of Ru-HT demonstrating RuII 3d5/2 and RuII 3d3/2 (spin-orbit separation = 4.1 eV) state at 282.83 eV and 286.0 eV respectively [44,45] (Fig. S4). The XPS analysis values confirm the Ru+2 oxidation conservation of Ru species in Ru-HT during the catalytic reaction which was found to be an active species for the formation of formic acid under the hired reaction conditions [46]. The XPS analysis of Ru-HT (Fresh catalyst) and RRu-HT (Reused catalyst) have been conducted and compared to each other (Fig. S4), which showed the same oxidation state (+2) of the ruthenium ion in the both, fresh and recycled catalyst. In order to find out the amount of ruthenium available in Ru-HT catalyst, 5 mg Ru-HT was digested using aqua regia (3:1 molar ratio of concentrated hydrochloric acid and nitric acid) and marked up to 50 mL in a measuring flask with distilled water. The prepared solution was subjected to inductively coupled plasma (ICP) mass spectrometry analysis, which showed the mean value of 0.487 mg/L (0.004 mmol) ruthenium present in Ru-HT catalyst (Table S1). Although the SEM-EDX analysis is only focused on a very small area of the samples, the presence of ruthenium ion in Ru-HT catalyst was also confirmed by it and we found 1.4 wt% of ruthenium ion available in the Ru-HT catalyst (Fig. S5). 3.2 Catalytic activity of Ru-HT All catalytic reactions were done in a 100 mL stainless steel Parr reactor by taking known amounts of Ru-HT catalyst, methanol, water, CO2 and H2. Ruthenium hydrotalcite (Ru-HT) catalyst was evaluated for the synthesis of formic acid by CO2 hydrogenation, the amount dependent data on CO2 conversion is displayed in Fig. 3 . TON values progressively increase as escalations of Ru-HT from 50 to 120 mg. A further boost in catalyst amount doesn’t make any effect on the TON values. Experimental studies showed that the synthesis of formic acid by the reaction of CO2 and H2 in methanol:water does not take place without a catalyst. Minimum 30 mg amount of Ru-HT is required to get a TON of 3797 for formic acid formation when 1:1, pCO2/pH2 (total pressure 50 bar) reacted together at 60 °C for 24 h. Interestingly, the conversion of formic acid was started to increase sufficiently when minimum 60 mg catalyst was taken (a TON of 7593) (Fig. 4 ). The pressure variation study revealed that minimum 60 bar pressure of CO2 + H2, 1:1 is required to obtain a TON of 11389 at 60 °C, having 100 mg catalyst, total 60 mL reaction media (methanol + water) during 24 h (Fig. 4). The yield of formic acid was not further increased by increasing the CO2 and H2 pressure under the identical reaction conditions. During the observation of the further reaction at 70–100 bar pressure the yield of formic acid started to remain constant, which was not further reached upto TON >11389 even after given more pressure than 100 bar (Fig. 4). The reaction time data given in Table 2 indicated that the conversion of formic acid is gradually increasing with increasing the reaction time, the ideal reaction time for the synthesis of formic acid in this catalytic system is 24 h. Under these conditions, the yield of formic acid is not increased beyond reaction hours and was remained close to constant with 24 h maximum (a TON of 11389) (Table 2). The formation of formic acid by CO2 hydrogenation mostly occurs with ΔG°298 = + 32.9 kJmol−1 and ΔH°298 = −31.6 kJmol−1, because of the entropy reason the value of ΔG is obtained positive. Hence, it is expected to decrease the equilibrium concentration of formic acid with increasing the reaction temperature. Because of the lower solubility of H2 and CO2 gases at a higher temperature, they could not contribute to increasing the more concentration of formic acid. Therefore, it is observed that increasing the reaction temperature from 60 °C to 100 °C could not affect the conversion of formic acid from CO2 hydrogenation and remain constant (Table 2). This shows the stability of the formed formic acid under the optimized reaction conditions at higher temperatures. The amount of solvent used for the hydrogenation of CO2 has an effect on the formation of formic acid. The reaction volume of 60 mL of methanol:water (5:1, v/v) was observed to be appropriate for the set reaction parameters. Decreasing this total reaction volume decrease the product formation as indicated in Table 2. The formation of formic acid in good TON value has been increased by increasing the amount of water added during the optimized reaction conditions because CO2 gas reacts with water to offer bicarbonates which possibly may act as a perfect substrate for the hydrogenation reaction. The reaction volume ratio of water and methanol has been varied in order to know the effect of the amount of water and methanol used as a reaction solvent under the optimized reaction conditions for the CO2 hydrogenation (Table S2). When, reaction volume ratio of water and methanol was taken 2:4 (v/v, 60 mL), then the TON of formation of formic acid is decreased to 759, which is 11389 for 1:5 ratio of H2O:MeOH (60 mL). The value of TON is continuously decreased on decreasing the volume of methanol and increasing the volume of water (Table S2, Entry 2–5), this is because of the solubility of gases dependent on the polarity of the solvents as the solubility of both gases is higher in methanol than water. A TON of 5315 was observed when only water was taken as a solvent, and a TON of 9111 was observed when only methanol was used as a solvent. 3.3 Catalytic activity and recyclability The catalyst was successfully recovered at the end of each catalytic cycle and washed with methanol then dried at 80 °C. The catalyst was then reused in the consequent recycling experiments and almost no loss was found in the formic acid formation as shown in Table 3 . The leaching of ruthenium ion was not found after the completion of the reaction which was confirmed by the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) mass spectrometry (Table S1) showing the results beyond the calibration range (0.3–10 ppm) with a negative mean value (−0.114 mgL−1) for the ruthenium ion. The isolated Ru-HT exhibited good catalytic activity having 11389 TON in 24 h even at the 7th catalytic cycle (Table 3), which indicates the catalytic and structural stability of the catalyst. Total 60 bar pressure of both gases CO2 and H2 and 60 °C temperature with low space velocity in 100 mL volume reactor are favorable for the hydrogenation of CO2. Comparable catalytic activities were observed for the fresh and recycled Ru-HT catalyst in the hydrogenation of CO2 reaction for the production of formic acid. 3.4 Reaction mechanisms Based on experimental observations, the reactants H2 and CO2 are to be activated by the catalyst, however, because of the less reactivity of CO2, H2 significantly contributes initially to facilitate the reaction in which H2 initially gets activated with the catalyst [47]. The reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid over Ru-HT is considered to propose via two plausible reaction pathways. The first one is a stepwise mechanism in which the grafted metal ion of Ru-HT (1) triggers H2 molecule (hydrogen gas) to form the hydride bonds with ruthenium ion for the formation of the intermediate (2). The reaction twitches with the absorption of CO2 on the surface of the catalyst and the bond between carbon and hydride of the metal ion for the formation of formate ion bonded with metal. The second one is based on water contribution to the reaction, which is more precise concerning an effectually active solvent molecule in the mechanistic path. Consequently, the dissociation of the coordinated water increases the scope for the successive insertion and coordination of CO2. The proposed schematic steps and mechanism are displayed in the Scheme 1 . The reaction proceeds bit fast and easy since H2 gets activated first by the catalyst (1) to form Ru-H2 (Ru-dihydride) (2) under the applied reaction conditions because the reactivity of CO2 is less than H2 [47,48]. In an equilibrium step, formate (3) forms by the reaction of Ru-dihydride (2) with CO2 through the insertion of CO2 into the one of the hydride bond. In the rate defining step, reductive elimination in formate (3) yields formic acid and the coordinatively unsaturated ruthenium species [49]. To complete the catalytic cycle, the rapid oxidative addition of dihydrogen regenerate the catalyst (1). The role of water during the reaction is to enhance the formation of formic acid, as the solubility of both gases in water is less than that of methanol used together. The solubility (mmol/L) of CO2 are 58.8 and 137.8, and of H2 are 0.68 and 3.86 at STP in water and methanol respectively [50]. Commonly, CO2 is more soluble in water and methanol (58.8 and 137.8 mmol/L at STP respectively) than H2 gas. Thus the taken volume of both solvents, particularly of methanol favors the reaction because the solubility of CO2 is more than two times more in methanol than water. During the catalytic mechanism, the operational effect was contributed by the molecular water, which increases the dissociation of the coordinated water and eases the consequential insertion and coordination of CO2 in high amount. The presence of water is reported to play a crucial role in the activation of CO2 [51]. The aquated Ru intermediate (4) reacted with one of the oxygen of CO2 for its coordination via the H-bonding interaction of the water, which clues the formation of the next intermediate (5). The insertion of CO2 in the Ru-H bond during the formate formation (6) caused the stabilization of the transition state between intermediate (5) and (6). This stabilization polarizes the fragment of CO2 by enhancing the electrophilicity of CO2 on the carbon and susceptibility of hydride transfer from Ru to yield formic acid along with the intermediate (7). This intermediate (7) undergoing rapid oxidative addition of dihydrogen formed the catalyst (1). 4 Conclusion 1. Active and reusable Ru-HT as a heterogeneous catalyst for the hydrogenation of CO2 for the synthesis of formic acid with a choice of ruthenium species has been developed and reported. 2. The oxidative +2 state of ruthenium ion was confirmed in Ru-HT catalyst through the XPS analysis, which was found to be an active state for the promising CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid under the hired reaction conditions. 3. Hydrotalcite supported Ru(II) based catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid have played a double role, (i) as a base/promoter and (ii) as a catalyst supporter. 4. Water and the hydrides played an important role in the activation of CO2 suitably to favor its hydrogenation, as the catalytic activity of Ru-HT for the CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid was dependent on the amount of water added and the hydrides formed during the reaction. 5. Activity and reusability of this catalyst are superior for the production of formic acid at moderate temperature (60 °C) and 60 bar pressure (CO2 and H2). 6. Maximum 11389 TON was achieved for the formic acid by the presented catalyst (Ru-HT), which was attributed to the 1st order reaction. coredata.dc:description: The reaction containing CO2 and H2 has been investigated for the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid using ruthenium hydrotalcite (Ru-HT) catalyst. Ruthenium salt was introduced to the synthesis of hydrotalcite as an active metal center to develop ruthenium based heterogeneous catalyst. Hydrotalcite not only acted as a support for the active metal but also acted as a soft solid base avoiding the use of the liquid base, which is normally required under homogeneous conditions for the formation of formic acid from the hydrogenation of CO2. Reaction temperatures were in the range of 40–100 °C, total pressure 10–100 bar with an ideal 1:1 ratio of pCO2:pH2. The maximum Turnover Number (TON) of 11389 was obtained for the formic acid formation under the optimized conditions at 60 °C temperature and 60 bar total pressure, using a mixture of methanol:water as a solvent (5:1, v/v). Ru-HT catalyst was synthesised and thorougly characterized by FT-IR, PXRD, SEM-EDX and surface area analysis. The catalyst was effectively recycled up to 7 times without any loss in catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Ruthenium-hydrotalcite (Ru-HT) as an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid
